questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with symptoms of tracheobronchitis and a persistent cough. After testing, Mycoplasma pneumoniae is identified as the causative agent. Which of the following is a notable feature of Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection that helps in its diagnosis?

choices.text: The presence of a characteristic "fried egg" colony appearance in blood agar culture
Detection of mycoplasma DNA through polymerase chain reaction (PCR)
High titers of cold agglutinins in the blood at 37°C
Indirect Coombs test detects red blood cells coated with antigens

questions.solution:
Answer: B) Detection of mycoplasma DNA through polymerase chain reaction (PCR)

 

Explanation:

PCR-based detection of mycoplasma DNA is a specific and effective method for diagnosing Mycoplasma pneumoniae infections.

 

Features of Mycoplasma:

  • Smallest free-living organism
  • Lack of cell wall (therefore Resistant to antibiotic interfering cell wall synthesis for ex:
  • B lactams), leading to pleomorphic nature
  • Cell membrane contains sterols
  • Ability to pass through standard bacterial filters
  • Historically misclassified as viruses (Joker of the microbiological park)
  • Chemoorganotrophs
  • Energy production via fermentation
  • Main energy sources: glucose or arginine

 

Clinical Features:

 

Pulmonary Infections:

Genital Infections:

Extrapulmonary Infections:
  • Causative Agent: Mycoplasma pneumoniae (mc cause of atypical pneumonia)
  • Common Name: Primary atypical pneumonia
  • Presentation: Tracheobronchitis, Acute pharyngitis (less common), Gradual onset of fever, malaise, headache, sore throat, Persistent cough, potentially blood-tinged sputum
  • Incidence: About one-third develop pneumonia
  • Incubation Period: 1 to 3 weeks
  • Diagnosis: Radiological assessments reveal patchy consolidation in lower lobes of lungs
  • Causative Agents: Mycoplasma hominis, Ureaplasma urealyticum
  • Transmission: Sexual contact
  • Conditions in Men: Urethritis, proctitis, balanoposthitis, Reiter's syndrome
  • Conditions in Women: Acute salpingitis, pelvic inflammatory disease, cervicitis, vaginitis, Infertility, abortion, postpartum fever, chorioamnionitis, low birth weight in infants

GI: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea

Cardiovascular: myocarditis, pericarditis

Neurological: meningitis, encephalitis, optic neuritis

Musculoskeletal/skin: Erythema multiforme, SJS, Maculopapular/vesicular rash

Others: cold AIHA, bullous myringitis, vasculitis

Diagnosis of Mycoplasma Infection

Method

Description

Details

Culture

Requires specialized media and has slow growth (Option A ruled out)
  • Takes 1 to 3 weeks for visible colonies
  • Colonies have a "fried egg" appearance (In PPLO agar, with Dienes stain)
  • M. pneumoniae shows beta-hemolysis and guinea pig red blood cell agglutination

Molecular Methods

Detects mycoplasma DNA
  • PCR is used for faster and more specific detection of DNA, particularly useful for slow-growing organisms

Serology

Detects antibodies in response to Mycoplasma infection

Specific Tests:

  • Immunofluorescence, hemagglutination inhibition, growth inhibition
  • Complement fixation, indirect hemagglutination (less sensitive)

Non-Specific Tests:

  • Streptococcus MG test: Agglutination with titre of 1:20 or higher
  • Cold agglutination test: where clumping of red blood cells is observed after the mixture is incubated at 4°C and disappears upon warming to 37°C (Option C ruled out); titre of 1:32 or greater
  • Indirect Coombs test: Detects red blood cells coated with antibodies. (Option D ruled out)

 

Treatment of Mycoplasma Infection

  • Antibiotics:
    • Tetracyclines (e.g., doxycycline)
    • Macrolides (e.g., erythromycin)
  • Concerns:
    • Emerging resistance, especially among certain Ureaplasma strains

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with fever, abdominal pain, and watery diarrhoea. The stool examination reveals the presence of leukocytes and blood. The patient has a history of consuming undercooked poultry. Direct microscopic examination of the stool shows darting motility of spiral rods. The laboratory report indicates that the pathogen is a Gram-negative rod that grows optimally at 42°C in microaerophilic conditions. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent of this infection?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Campylobacter jejuni

 

Explanation:

Campylobacter jejuni is known to cause diarrheal disease with symptoms including fever, abdominal pain, and watery diarrhoea. The presence of darting motility in stool, growth at 42°C, and a history of consuming undercooked poultry are characteristic of Campylobacter jejuni. It is a Gram-negative, spiral-shaped rod and is strongly oxidase-positive.

Scanning electron micrograph of the single polar flagellum and corkscrew shape of Campylobacter jejuni. These morphologic characteristics contribute to the characteristic darting motility of C jejuni.

 

Campylobacter Features:

Feature

Description

Morphology and Structure

Slender, spirally curved, Gram-negative rods; comma-shaped, may form 'S' or multispiral chains; non-sporing; single unsheathed polar flagellum

Growth Conditions

Microaerophilic; 5% oxygen concentration; thermophilic species grow at 42°C; strongly oxidase positive

Pathogenic Significance

Campylobacter jejuni is the most common cause of bacterial diarrheal disease in developed countries

Clinical Features:

Aspect

Description

Infection Pathway

Ingestion; primary sites: jejunum and ileum; may spread to colon and rectum

Pathogenesis

Invasive pathogen; incubation period: 1-7 days; damages small intestine cells, disrupting fluid absorption

Symptoms

Fever, abdominal pain, watery diarrhea; stool may contain leukocytes and blood; typically self-limiting with possible continued shedding

Diagnosis:

Method

Description

Direct Microscopic Examination

Phase-contrast or dark field microscopy for motility; stained smears for detection of small curved rods

Culture Techniques

Plated on selective media; use transport medium if delayed; commonly used media include Skirrow's, Butzler's, Campy BAP

Incubation Conditions

42°C with 5% oxygen, 10% CO₂, 85% N₂; also at 37°C; suppresses normal fecal flora

Colony Appearance

Non-hemolytic, grey/colorless, moist, flat/convex; appears in 48 hours

Identification

Gram staining, motility, oxidase tests; biochemical tests for confirmation (positive catalase and nitrate reduction)

Treatment

Treatment Type

Description

Primary Treatment

Fluid and electrolyte replacement

Antibiotic Therapy

Erythromycin is the preferred antibiotic

 

Salmonella enterica (Option A): Although it is associated with poultry, Salmonella typically does not display darting motility or a spiral shape and does not grow optimally at 42°C in microaerophilic conditions.

 

Shigella dysenteriae (Option B): Shigella is a Gram-negative rod but does not have darting motility or a spiral shape, nor does it require microaerophilic conditions or high temperatures for growth.

 

Escherichia coli (Option D): While certain strains can cause bloody diarrhea, E. coli is not spiral-shaped and does not exhibit darting motility or a growth preference at 42°C under microaerophilic conditions.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with chronic gastritis undergoes diagnostic testing for Helicobacter pylori infection. The tests include both invasive and non-invasive methods. Which of the following non-invasive tests is specifically known for its ability to detect active H. pylori infection and provide rapid results?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Urea Breath Test

 

Explanation:

The Urea Breath Test is a non-invasive test that involves ingesting carbon-labelled urea, which is broken down by H. pylori to release carbon dioxide that is measured in the breath. It is specifically known for detecting active infection and provides rapid and reliable results. The other options are invasive modalities.

Helicobacter pylori:

  • Genetic Diversity and Pathogenesis
    • H. pylori exhibits significant genetic diversity, impacting its virulence.
    • Key genes: cag (cytotoxin-associated gene) and vac (vacuolating cytotoxin gene).
    • Contributes to pathogenesis via urease production and motility.
  • Clinical Manifestations
    • Range from asymptomatic colonization to severe gastric diseases.
    • Potential outcomes include peptic ulcer disease, chronic atrophic gastritis, gastric adenocarcinoma, and MALT lymphomas.
  • Immune Response
    • The infection triggers a complex immune response involving IgM, IgG, IgA, and cellular immunity.
    • Immune response does not effectively protect against infection.

Diagnosis of H. pylori Infection

Invasive Tests

  • Endoscopic Biopsy: Tissue sample from the gastric mucosa. (Option A rule out)
    • Rapid Urease Test: Detects urease in the biopsy; results available within minutes. (Option C ruled out)
    • Microscopy: Identifies H. pylori through staining (Warthin starry stain)
    • Culture: Most sensitive method; involves growing bacteria from a biopsy on a nutrient-rich medium under specific conditions (37°C, microaerophilic environment). Results in 3-7 days. Further characterization includes biochemical tests (catalase and oxidase positive). (Option D ruled out)

Non-Invasive Tests

  • Serology (ELISA): Detects antibodies against H. pylori; useful for epidemiological studies, less reliable for diagnosing active infection or monitoring treatment.
  • Urea Breath Test: Involves ingestion of carbon-labeled urea; breakdown by H. pylori releases carbon dioxide, measured in breath. Sensitive and reliable, but requires specialized equipment.

Treatment

  • Antibiotic and Bismuth Salt Regimen
    • Standard treatment: Bismuth subsalicylate + two antibiotics (tetracycline or amoxicillin + metronidazole) for two weeks.
    • Alternative: Proton pump inhibitor (e.g., omeprazole) + clarithromycin.
  • Indications for Treatment
    • Recommended for H. pylori-associated gastric or duodenal ulcers.
    • Asymptomatic colonization does not require treatment.
  • Challenges
    • Increasing antibiotic resistance.
    • High rate of infection recurrence.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with fever, non-productive cough, and shortness of breath. A chest X-ray shows signs of pneumonia. Suspecting Legionnaires' disease, a sputum sample is cultured on Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract (BCYE) agar. Which of the following findings on BCYE agar is indicative of Legionella growth?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Black or grayish colonies

 

Explanation:

On Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract (BCYE) agar, Legionella species typically form small, grayish or black colonies due to the reduction of iron salts in the medium. This color change is distinctive for Legionella and aids in its identification.

 

Legionella

Features

  • Thin, Gram-negative, non-capsulated bacilli (2-5 x 0.1-0.3 µm).
  • Poor Gram staining; best visualized by direct fluorescent antibody (DFA) staining.
  • Requires buffered charcoal yeast extract (BCYE) agar for growth.

Clinical Features

Condition

Characteristics

Severity

Legionnaires' Disease

Fever, non-productive cough, dyspnea, progressing to pneumonia, diarrhea, encephalopathy, causes SIADH (hyponatremia, seizures)

Causes both typical and atypical pneumonia.

Mode of infection:

  • microaspiration and aerosol inhalation
  • There is no human to human transmission

Associated with: AC, showers, coolers, cruise

Seen in : Smokers, immunocompromised patients, older patients

High (15-20% fatality)

Pontiac Fever

Mild, non-fatal symptoms: fever, chills, myalgia, headache

Mild

Diagnosis Methods

Method

Sample Type

Notes

Direct Fluorescent Antibody (DFA)

Sputum, bronchial aspirate, lung biopsy

Detects Legionella in specimens

Culture

Clinical specimens
  • Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract (BCYE) Agar- Gold standard for Legionella culture; contains yeast extract, iron, L-cysteine, and charcoal; optimal pH ~6.9
  • Small colonies, often grayish or black, due to iron reduction by bacteria. (Option C)
  • L-cysteine Presence: Required for growth, confirming presumptive Legionella colonies.

Antigen Detection in Urine

Urine

Latex agglutination or ELISA

Serum Antibody Detection

Blood

ELISA or indirect immunofluorescence

 

Treatment

  • First-line options: Macrolides, ciprofloxacin, tetracyclines.
  • Severe cases: Rifampicin may be added.
  • Ineffective antibiotics: Beta-lactamase antibiotics and aminoglycosides.

Blue-green pigment (Option A): It is characteristic of Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

 

Yellow colonies (Option B): Legionella does not produce yellow colonies on BCYE agar.

 

Hemolytic zones (Option D): Legionella does not typically cause hemolysis on BCYE agar.

questions.text: A microbiologist is studying Klebsiella pneumoniae and its microscopic characteristics. Which of the following statements about the microscopy of Klebsiella pneumoniae is true?

choices.text: It is Gram-positive and appears purple under Gram staining
Its capsule is visible using the Warthin-Starry method.
They are observed as elongated, slender rods that are encapsulated
There is an absence of biofilm when examined with a scanning electron microscope (SEM).

questions.solution:
Answer: B) Its capsule is visible using the Warthin-Starry method.

 

Explanation:

The Warthin-Starry method is a specific staining technique that highlights the polysaccharide capsule of Klebsiella pneumoniae, which plays a crucial role in its virulence by helping it evade phagocytosis.

Klebsiella:

Features
  • Non-motile, capsulated, short, plump rods (1-2 µm x 0.5-1.8 µm).
  • Common as intestinal commensals and saprophytes in soil and water.
  • Ferment glucose, lactose, sucrose, and mannitol, producing acid and gas

Clinical Features

Major healthcare-associated pathogen, commonly causing:

  • Pneumonia (upper lobe pneumonia): Severe, often affecting middle-aged/older adults with risk factors (e.g., alcoholism, diabetes).
  • UTIs, particularly catheter-associated (CAUTI).
  • Lung abscess, red current jelly sputum, bulging fissure sign
  • Neonatal sepsis: High mortality due to multidrug resistance.
  • Septicemia and other pyogenic infections.

Morphological Characteristics
  • Appears as short, plump, encapsulated rods with visible halos in Gram-stained smears. (Option C ruled out)

Gram Staining
  • Gram-negative; appears pink after counterstaining with safranin. (Option A ruled out)
  • Typically rod-shaped (bacilli).

Capsule Visualization
  • Encapsulation visualized using staining techniques (e.g., Warthin-Starry method, India ink preparation), highlighting the polysaccharide capsule, crucial for evading phagocytosis.

Fluorescence Microscopy
  • Used to assess antibiotic efficacy (e.g., meropenem) and monitor morphological changes post-treatment, showing enlarged or distorted cells.

Biofilm Structure
  • Studied using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) to visualize complex biofilm architecture, essential for understanding bacterial adherence and interaction with surfaces. (Option D ruled out)

Biochemical tests:

Treatment

Empiric therapy for bloodstream infections often needed:

  • Options include piperacillin-tazobactam, cefoperazone-sulbactam, or amikacin.
  • Carbapenems (imipenem, meropenem) are preferred for resistant or critical cases.

Klebsiella Infections:

Aspect

Description

Common Infections

Pneumonia, UTIs, septicemia, neonatal sepsis, pyogenic infections

High-Risk Groups

Middle-aged/older adults with comorbidities (alcoholism, diabetes), neonates, ICU patients

Mortality Factors

High for pneumonia and neonatal sepsis, often due to multidrug-resistant strains

 

Treatment:

Infection Type

Initial Empiric Treatment

Resistant/Critical Cases Treatment

Bloodstream Infections

Piperacillin-tazobactam, cefoperazone-sulbactam, amikacin

Carbapenems (imipenem, meropenem)

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the diagnosis of Francisella tularensis infection (tularemia) is true?

choices.text: Culturing F. tularensis is easily performed on standard blood agar.
Serological tests are always reliable and do not require confirmation with other diagnostic methods
Direct microscopy of patient samples is the primary method for diagnosis
Isolation of the organism from clinical specimens is essential for confirming tularemia

questions.solution:
Answer: D) Isolation of the organism from clinical specimens is essential for confirming tularemia.

 

Explanation:

Isolation of Francisella tularensis from clinical specimens, such as blood or tissue samples, is the gold standard for diagnosing tularemia. This method provides definitive evidence of the pathogen's presence, while other methods, like serological tests, may not be reliable in all cases and could lead to false negatives. Therefore, culture confirmation is crucial for accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

Francisella tularensis

  • Characteristics:
    • Minute, capsulated, non-motile, Gram-negative bacillus.
    • Filterable and capable of filament formation and budding, similar to Mycoplasma.
  • Strains are classified into biotypes based on virulence and epidemiological behavior:
    • Highly virulent strains are exclusive to North America.
    • Low-virulence strains are found in Europe and Asia.

Clinical Features

  • Francisella tularensis causes tularemia, a zoonotic infection transmitted to humans from rabbits and rodents.
  • Transmission occurs via:
    • Tick bites
    • Ingestion of contaminated meat or water
    • Inhalation of infectious aerosols
  • Clinical manifestations include:
    • Tularemia also called ulceroglandular fever: Local ulceration with lymphadenopathy
    • Typhoid-like fever with glandular swelling
    • Influenza-like respiratory symptoms

Disease progression:

Ticket bite during rabbit killing → hand ulcer → axillary lymphadenitis

 

Diagnosis

  • Diagnosis of tularemia can be achieved through several methods:

Method

Description

Culture

Requires specialized media (e.g., Francis’ blood dextrose cystine agar); small transparent colonies appear after 3-5 days of incubation. (Option A ruled out)

Animal Inoculation

Identified by inoculating guinea pigs or mice with patient samples.

Serology

Detection of agglutinating antibodies in patient sera. Can yield false negatives and therefore require further confirmation with cultures.(Option B ruled out)

Treatment

  • An attenuated vaccine can be given by scarification to high-risk individuals.

Direct microscopy of patient samples is the primary method for diagnosis (Option C): Direct microscopy is not the primary method for diagnosing tularemia. While it can be used to visualize organisms in tissue samples, it is not sufficiently sensitive or specific to serve as the main diagnostic tool.

questions.text:
Match the following features/diseases with their respective organisms:


	
		
			
			1. Klebsiella pneumoniae
			
			
			a. Chronic granulomatous hypertrophy of nose
			
		
		
			
			2. Klebsiella ozaenae
			
			
			b. Foul-smelling nasal discharge
			
		
		
			
			3. Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis
			
			
			c. Healthcare-associated infections, UTI, septicemia
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) 1-c; 2-b; 3-a

Explanation:

1. Klebsiella pneumoniae

c. Healthcare-associated infections, UTI, septicemia

2. Klebsiella ozaenae

b. Foul-smelling nasal discharge

3. Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis

a. Chronic granulomatous hypertrophy of nose

 

1. Klebsiella pneumoniae (Friedlander's bacillus, Bacillus mucosus capsulatus) :

  • They grow well on ordinary media, forming large, dome-shaped, mucoid colonies of varying degrees of stickiness.
  • On MacConkey agar, they grow as lactose-forming colonies
  • Common infections associated with K. pneumoniae are pneumonia, urinary infection, septicemia, several pyogenic infections and, very rarely, diarrhea

Pneumonia due to Klebsiella is a serious disease with high case fatality:

  • It occurs in middle-aged or older persons with risk factors such as alcoholism, chronic bronchopulmonary disease or diabetes mellitus.
  • The disease is characterized by massive mucoid inflammatory exudate of lobar or lobular distribution, involving one or more lobes of the lung.
  • Necrosis and abscess formation are more frequent than in pneumococcal pneumonia. Serotypes 1, 2 and 3 are usually responsible for pneumonia.

K.pneumoniae is a frequent cause of :

  • Urinary infection, often causing catheter-associated UTI (CAUTI).
  • As most strains are resistant to antibiotics, treatment poses serious problems.
  • It also causes pyogenic infections such as abscesses, meningitis and septicemia.
  • Mortality is high in neonatal sepsis caused by Klebsiella pneumoniae, as mostly multidrug-resistant strains cause these infections.

2. K.ozaenae :

  • It is a bacillus associated with ozena, a disease characterized by foul-smelling nasal discharge.
  • Identification is difficult due to wide variations in the biochemical reactions of individual strains.
  • K.ozaenae belongs to capsular types 3-6.

3. K.rhinoscleromatis:

  • It causes rhinoscleroma, a chronic granulomatous hypertrophy of the nose.
  • The bacilli are seen intracellularly in lesions.
  • It can be identified by biochemical reactions and belongs to capsular type 3

Biochemical reaction differentiating Klebsiella species:

  • Klebsiella ferment carbohydrates (glucose, lactose, sucrose and mannitol) with the production of acid and abundant gas.
  • The IMViC reaction is - -+ +.

Treatment:

  • Empiric treatment is done for bloodstream infections. 4.5 g of Piperacillin + Tazobactam every six hours OR
  • 3 g of Cefoperazone-sulbactam every 12 hours or Aminoglycoside, e.g., amikacin 20 mg/ kg/ day must be given.
  • Carbapenems like imipenem and Meropenem must be given in resistant isolates and critically ill patients.
